elements.label: header
elements.text:
MAT 186
Quiz 6

elements.label: para
elements.text: 1. Find the local and (if they exist) global extrema of $y=3x^4+8x^3+\frac{15}{2}x^2+3x-\frac{7}{2}$.

elements.label: tab
elements.text: AB6CF12CF13MW3

elements.label: para
elements.text: So, the critical points are at $x=-1$ and $x=-\frac{1}{2}$.

elements.label: para
elements.text:
However, the function is decreasing on $x < 1$ and increasing on $x > 1$, so we end up with $x = -\frac{1}{2}$ being
neither a maximum nor a minimum. $x = 1$ gives the only minimum and the function increases without
bound on either side of the point. Therefore, $(-1,-4)$ is a global minimum.

elements.label: para
elements.text:
2. The function $y=x^3+x^2-8x-12$ has one positive $x-1$
intercept. We build a rectangle with horizontal and vertical sides that
has the origin as one vertex and a point on the graph of y for its opposite vertex. If this second
point lies between the $y-$ and $x-$ intercepts of the graph, what value(s) would maximize the
area of the rectangle?

elements.label: para
elements.text:
Factoring $y$, we get $y = (x+2)^2(x-3)$, so the second point has $0 \leq x \leq 3$. We should also note
that the point will have a negative $y$ value, as that will make a difference for the question.

elements.label: para
elements.text:
If we write the point on the graph as $(x,x^3+x^2-8x-12)$ , then the area of the rectangle created
would be $A(x)=-x(x^3+x^2-8x-12)$ , because of the negative coordinate. You can do the
question without the negative for now, but it is a little trickier.

elements.label: para
elements.text: Therefore, we have $A(x)=-x^{4}-x^{3}+8 x^{2}+12 x$ and can get going:

elements.label: para
elements.text:
Of these, the first two points are outside our domain, so they can be dismissed. We are left with $x=2$ as the only critical point in the interval. We can compare its $y-$ value with that of the other two
endpoints, analyze using the first derivative test, or go to the second derivative test, as long as we do

elements.label: foot
elements.text: Continued on back.

elements.label: half_para
elements.text:
at least one of them. If you did not realize earlier that the point lies below the axis, you will find that
$x=2$ gives a minimum, but that it is still the correct value.

elements.label: para
elements.text: Therefore, the maximum area occurs at $x=2$.

elements.label: sec_1
elements.text:
3. Use two linear approximations (that is, use a different initial point each time) to
estimate $\sqrt[3]{4}$

elements.label: para
elements.text:
You will find that the better approximation has a larger value for dx (for comparison $\sqrt[3]{4} \approx 1.59$ ).
How could this happen?

elements.label: para
elements.text:
I took a gamble here that everyone would use the function $y = \sqrt[3]{x}$ and attempt to use $a = 1$ and $a = 8$.
(Note that $a = 0$ will not work because $y$ is not differentiable there.)

elements.label: para
elements.text: For our function, we have $y'=\frac{1}{3x^{2/3}}$. We have:

elements.label: tab
elements.text:
a18
y(a)12
dx=x-a3-4
m=y'(a)1/31/12
dy=m·dx1-1/3
$\sqrt[3]{4}\approx y(a)+dy$25/3

elements.label: para
elements.text:
There are a few ways of thinking about why $a=8$ gives the more accurate answer. It originates with the fact
that the graph of $y=\sqrt[3]{x}$ is `more flat' the further you go. That is, its second derivative is smaller, so the graph
stays close to its tangent lines for longer. We can also think about the tangent lines themselves $-$ since the
function is concave down, the lines all lie above the graph, but at $x=4$, the tangent line that starts at $a=8$
lies below the one from $a=1$.

elements.label: para
elements.text:
[The following question is strictly to help with older marks – the mark will NOT lower your grade.
If you are doing well with the squeeze theorem (CS2) and domains of functions (AB6), this will not
help your mark much, but you are welcome to answer it.]

elements.label: sec_1
elements.text: 4. Find $\lim_{x \to 2}(x-2)\cos \Big(\frac{1}{(x-2)^2}\Big)$. AB6 CS2 MW2

elements.label: para
elements.text: This definitely requires the Squeeze Theorem, with positive and negative cases.

elements.label: para
elements.text: Case I: $x-2>0,$ or $x>2.$

elements.label: equ
elements.text: $$-1 \leq \cos \left(\frac{1}{(x-2)^{2}}\right) \leq 1$$

elements.label: equ
elements.text: $$-(x-2) \leq(x-2) \cos \left(\frac{1}{(x-2)^{2}}\right) \leq(x-2)$$

elements.label: para
elements.text: Therefore, by the Squeeze Theorem, the limit in case I goes to zero.

elements.label: para
elements.text:
Case II is nearly identical and we can get away with saying “Case II is done similarly.” Here it is in
full:

elements.label: para
elements.text: Case II: $x-2<0$, or $x<2$.

elements.label: equ
elements.text: $$-1 \leq \cos \left(\frac{1}{(x-2)^{2}}\right) \leq 1$$

elements.label: equ
elements.text: $$-(x-2) \geq(x-2) \cos \left(\frac{1}{(x-2)^{2}}\right) \geq(x-2)$$

elements.label: para
elements.text: Therefore, by the Squeeze Theorem, the limit in case II goes to zero.

elements.label: para
elements.text: Therefore, the limit is zero.
